prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our main driver is to detect cold dust around White Dwarfs using band-6. We request a continuum rms sensitivity of 0.040 mJy. This value will allow us to reach a 3-sigma dust mass level ranging from 0.15 to 1.2 Moon masses for most of the disks, depending on their distance. Given that the amount of cold dust is expected to vary with time and from system to system it is fundamental for our project to be sensitive to such small dust masses. With the strong constraints at hand, we will be able to measure the evolution of the dust mass as a function of age thereby providing the first direct insight into the dynamical post main-sequence evolution of planets and planetesimals. We will use the results to test and further develop our models for evolved planetary systems. Based on the ALMA OT calculator, the requested continuum sensitivity translates into a total of 1.76 hours of ALMA time, including calibrations and overheads.

Correlator setup: We will make use of the spectral line mode in Band 6, with 1.875 GHz bandwidth each, implying a total bandwidth of 7.5 GHz for continuum measurements. We will have 3 spectral windows aiming to maximize pure continuum sensitivity with 31.25 MHz width channels. One spectral window includes the CO(2-1) line with 976.563 kHz spectral resolution. The requested CO line bandwidth is aimed at maximizing the continuum detection. We do not expect to detect CO but we can not completely rule out the existence of cold gas in the evolved planetary systems we are observing. As it does not harm our contimuum measurements, the gas line is included in our set-up as a secondary goal that does not affect the main goal of the observations. For the CO(2-1) line measurement, the continuum sensitivity value will imply an rms of 4 mJy per 0.488 MHz channel. For an assumed line width of 3km/s, the resolution of 1.2 km/s implies that any (very unlikely) CO detection will only be marginally resolved.

Antenna setup: We aim for maximizing the sensitivity for the detection of continuum emmision. We therefore require our targets not to be resolved. Consequently, we request these observations to be carried out in a compact configuration (C36-1, C36-2, C36-3). This will guarantee enough short baselines, optimizing the total flux measurement.

Our main driver is to detect cold dust around White Dwarfs using band-6. We request a continuum rms sensitivity of 0.040 mJy. This value will allow us to reach a 3-sigma dust mass level ranging from 0.15 to 1.2 Moon masses for most of the disks, depending on their distance. Given that the amount of cold dust is expected to vary with time and from system to system it is fundamental for our project to be sensitive to such small dust masses. With the strong constraints at hand, we will be able to measure the evolution of the dust mass as a function of age thereby providing the first direct insight into the dynamical post main-sequence evolution of planets and planetesimals. We will use the results to test and further develop our models for evolved planetary systems. Based on the ALMA OT calculator, the requested continuum sensitivity translates into a total of 2.1 hours of ALMA time, including calibrations and overheads.

Correlator setup: We will make use of the spectral line mode in Band 6, with 1.875 GHz bandwidth each, implying a total bandwidth of 7.5 GHz for continuum measurements. We will have 3 spectral windows aiming to maximize pure continuum sensitivity with 31.25 MHz width channels. One spectral window includes the CO(2-1) line with 976.563 kHz resolution. The requested CO line bandwidth is aimed at maximizing the continuum detection. We do not expect to detect CO but we can not completely rule out the existence of cold gas in the evolved planetary systems we are observing. As it does not harm our contimuum measurements, the gas line is included in our set-up as a secondary goal that does not affect the main goal of the observations. For the CO(2-1) line measurement, the continuum sensitivity value will imply an rms of 4 mJy per 0.488 MHz channel. For an assumed line width of 3 km/s, the resolution of 1.2 km/s implies that any (very unlikely) CO detection will only be marginally resolved.

Antenna setup: We aim for maximizing the sensitivity for the detection of continuum emmision. We therefore require our targets not to be resolved. Consequently, we request these observations to be carried out in a compact configuration (C36-1, C36-2, C36-3). This will guarantee enough short baselines, optimizing the total flux measurement.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Over the past few years it has become increasingly clear that evolved planetary systems around white dwarfs are as frequent, and varied, as those around main sequence stars. Compact debris discs, formed by the tidal disruption of planetesimals, are found around many single white dwarfs, and transit timing variations reveal the presence of circumbinary planets around eclipsing white dwarf binaries. We detect large amounts of cool dust around one of these binaries, NN Ser, in our ALMA Cycle 2 data. Here, we propose an efficiently designed ALMA survey for cool dust around one dozen single and binary white dwarfs spanning cooling ages from ~50 Myr to ~1 Gyr. The evolution of the dust mass as a function of age will provide the first direct insight into the dynamical post main-sequence evolution of planets and planetesimals, and we will use the results to test and further develop our models for evolved planetary systems.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: We recently performed a pilot study in cycle 2 aimimg for a detection of cold dust around the white dwarf binary NN Ser (proposal 2013.1.00468.S). The data was delivered one week before the cycle 3 deadline and indeed we detected 1 Earth mass of dust.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
